Methodology

Step By Step Guide

Data Sources:

Data

Link

Description / Usage

Libya Derna City outline

Derna_city_250m_hexagon layer provided by prof

Used to contextualise project scope

Libya Waterways

https://data.humdata.org/dataset/hotosm_lby_waterways

Used for proximity to waterways layer in Flood Risk Map

Libya Derna DEM

https://earthexplorer.usgs.gov/

Used for Elevation and Slope layer in Flood Risk Map

Libya Roads Network

(OpenStreetMap Export)

https://data.humdata.org/dataset/hotosm_lby_roads

Including manual edits and incorporation of roads not represented by OSM data using satellite imagery from https://openaerialmap.org/

Used as network layer for Service and Accessibility Mapping

Libya Places of Worship

(OpenStreetMap Export)

https://download.geofabrik.de/africa/libya.html

Used to identify public facilities (i.e. mosque) as potential evacuation sites

Libya Places of Interest

(OpenStreetMap Export)

https://download.geofabrik.de/africa/libya.html

Used to identify public facilities (i.e. community centre, mall, colleges) as potential evacuation sites

Libya buildings

From OSM: (Chosen because some building classification info is included) https://data.humdata.org/dataset/hotosm_lby_buildings

Used as an approximation for population density

Used to identify public facilities (i.e. university and hospital)

Flood Risk Map

Derna Slope Layer

  1. Import Elevation Layer

  • Import the DEM layer into qGIS

  1. Compute Slope

  • From the menu bar, select Raster, click Analysis and click Slope
  • For Input layer, select DEM from the drop-down list
  • Click on Run button.
  • Export the Slope layer and call it Slope

Derna Waterways Layer

Extract Vector data

  • Import the gis_osm_waterways_free_1 and Dern_city_250m_hexagon
  • From the menu bar, click on Vector, then click Geoprocessing Tools and click Clip
  • For Input layer, select gis_osm_waterways_free_1
  • For Output layer, select Dern_city_250m_hexagon
  • Click on Run and then Close
  • A new clipped layer should be created, right click on it, Export, Save Selected Features as
  • Call the layer waterways

Extract Raster Data

  • Import the DEM layer
  • From the menu bar, click on Raster, then click Extraction and Clip Raster by Extent
  • For Input layer, select DEM
  • Under Clipping Extent, click on the icon at the end of the option then select Calculate from Layer
  • Select Derna from drop-down list
  • Export the new Clipped (extent) layer and save it as DEM

Rasterise waterways layer

  • Open the attribute table of the waterways layer
  • Click on Open field calculator
  • Under Output Field, type POI_CODE
  • At Expression pane, type 1
  • Click OK
  • From the menu bar select Raster, Conversion, Rasterise (Vector to Raster)
  • For Input layer, select waterway from the drop-down list
  • For Field to use for a burn-in value, select POI_CODE from the drop-down list
  • For Output raster size units, select Georeferenced units
  • Keep both horizontal and vertical resolutions at 5 (meaning 5m by 5m resolution)
  • For Output extent, click on Calculate from Layer
  • Select DEM from the drop-down list
  • Click Run and then close
  • Export the new Rasterized layer and save it as raster_waterway

Compute proximity of waterway

  • For the menu bar, select Raster, then click Analysis and click Proximity (Raster Distance)
  • For Input layer, select raster_waterway from the drop-down list.
  • For Distance units, select Georeferenced coordinates from the drop-down list
  • For Output data type, select Float32 from the drop-down list
  • Click Run
  • Export the Proximity map and call it derna_prox_waterways

Flood Risk Map

  1. Combine factor layers

Normalise DEM, Slope and Proximity Layer

  • Under Processing Toolbox, search for Fuzzify raster (linear membership)
  • Under Input Raster, select Slope
  • for Low fuzzy membership bound, enter the max value of the slope
  • for High fuzzy membership bound, enter the min value of the slope
  • Click Run and export Fuzzified_raster as norm_Slop
  • Repeat these steps for DEM and derna_prox_waterways, save the normalised layers as norm_prox_waterway and norm_DEM

  1. AHP Analysis

  • Using the AHP Template, change the number of factors to 3
  • Key in the weightage as such according to

  • Return to QGIS and open raster calculator
  • Key in the following expression: ("norm_Slope@1" * 0.159) + ("norm_DEM@1" * 0.252) + ("norm_prox_waterway@1" * 0.589)
  • Set the reference layer CRS to norm_Slope
  • Set the output CRS to 3177
  • Click Run, export Output as factor_suitability

  1. Classify flood zones (high, medium and low risk)

Identify Suitable Sites

  • Under Processing Toolbox, search for Reclassify by Table
  • Select factor_suitability as Raster layer
  • At the end of Reclassification table, click the 3 dots
  • Add 3 rows and assign values to the table based on the following classification rule:

Classification Rule:

Low risk

0.5 to 0.8

Medium risk

0.8 to 0.9

High risk

0.9 and above

  • Click run and export Reclassified raster as MCDA_model

Vectorise flood susceptibility zones

  • From the menu bar, select Raster, click Conversion and click Polygonize(Raster to Vector)
  • For Input Layer, select MCDA_model
  • Keep the checkbox in front of Use 8-connectedness uncheck.
  • Click Run, export the newly created vector layer as flood_susceptibility
  • Double click the layer, click Single Symbol and change it to Categorised
  • Select DN, select Blues on Color Ramp and click classify
  • Click Apply

The final map is as shown above, where the darker blue regions are the ones with high flood risk, lighter blue medium flood risk and white with the lowest flood risk as defined by the table below

Low risk

0.5 to 0.8

Medium risk

0.8 to 0.9

High risk

0.9 and above

Potential Evacuation Sites

Potential Evacuation Sites Layer

  1. Gather public facilities as potential site

Using places of interest vector data layer from OSM, we identify the following public facilities: community centre, mall, educational facilities.

Using places of Worship layer from OSM, we identify and save it as mosques layer in libya.

Using buildings data from OSM, we identify public facilities through “Selection by Expression” using the following statement.

We create centroids to represent these identified buildings

Finally we save this layer as potential sites.

Afterwards, we merge all the layers using Merge vector layers:

  1. Filter sites by Flood Risk Zones

Finally only 20 evacuation sites that are not part of high risk flood zones are selected

Service Area and Accessibility Map

Roads Layer:

1. Fixing Broken Road lines:

1.1 Extracting Derna’s Aerial Map:

Go to https://openaerialmap.org/ and search for Derna’s Aerial Map.

Remember to Sign In before searching for “Derna” in the System.

Choose the image that contains the image of Derna before the flood incident.

Your screen should look like the screenshot below.

Download the file by clicking on the download button.

Your screen should look like the screenshot below:

Save the file into a new folder under GIS Project. You can name it “Derna Tiff”.

Open the file in your QGIS.

Your screen should look like the screenshot below:

1.2 Selecting all road network with the study area

DIY: Download OSM roads data from the OSM folder and import it into QGIS (Ideally, the shapefile version should be used). Then, save the GIS layer into GeoPackage format. Name the output layer as roads.

Your screen should look like the screenshot below:

1.3 Creating the missing roads

  • Click on Toggle editing

  • Click on Add Line Feature

Your screen should look like the screenshot below:

  • Add the specific lines for the missing roads

After adding the specific line, your screen should look like the screenshot below:

Fill in the fclass based on the road type that the road was joined with. You may refer to the attribute table to determine which fclass to put. After you have fill in the specific feature attributes,

  • Click OK

Your new road would appear, like the screenshot below:

DIY: Repeat the joining of new roads until you have joined all the roads you need.

Your screen should look like the screenshot below:

Now, we will proceed to save the newly created roads.

  • In the panel layer, Right click on Roads > Save Layer Edits

2. Split roads based on flood risk regions

2.1 Clip roads based on the flood risk regions

To do this part we need to add the flood risk map created from before as a vector layer on top of the processed roads layer we created from Step 1.

For this analysis all roads are used given the assumption that traffic and road delineations no longer apply in the case of a disaster.

Firstly, we will be selecting all the roads that fall in respective flood risk area based on the flood risk map as indicated from the raster layer we found in the above section using the Clip function.

1. clip with each polygon (high medium low)

1.5 add column for speed of respective zone

2. merge with merge vector layers under processing tools

3. delete the fi field afterwards (cuz now theres duplicates of the same road, since its clipped and broken up) so that qgis generates new fid

4. save as merge layer

2.2 Add custom speed column as attribute for respective roads layer

  • After successfully running, in the layer panel, right click on study_area_driveable_roads and open attribute table

Your attribute table should look like the screenshot below, with certain rows selected in blue:

Now, we are going to edit the Speed column values for those highlighted in blue and set all their values to 0. This is to ensure that the calculation for shortest and fastest distance does not take into account of these roads in the high risk flood prone areas.

  • Click on Open Field Calculator
  • Tick “Update existing field”
  • Choose from the dropdown “Speed:
  • Key in the 0 as shown in the screenshot shown below:

  • Click OK
  • Close the Attribute table field
  • Click Save and Turn off toggle editing mode

Thereafter, save the layer as roads_for_high_risk_flood

These steps are repeated for medium and low flood risk roads as well.

2.3 Merge respective roads layer using Merge Vector Layers

This is done using merge vector layers tool under processing tools

 

Thereafter, take note to delete the FID field before saving so that qGIS will generate a new unique FID field upon saving. Otherwise, there will be a unique FID error since there are now duplicates of the same road that have been clipped and duplicated.

Finally, save this layer as merge layer named merged_roads_0_2_5kmh

Service Area Mapping

1. Individual Service Area Map for each evacuation site

1.1 Use QNEAT IsoArea as Polygon for Fastest Distance Analysis:

In this sub-section, you are going to learn how to delineate a 30-min evacuation centre area by using QNEAT3.

  • From QGIS’s menu bar, select Processing -> Toolbox.

The Processing Toolbox panel appears.

  • Select QNEATS3 -> Iso-Areas -> Iso-Area as Polygons (from Layer).

The Iso-Area as Polygons (From Layer) dialog window appears.

  • For Vector layer representing network, select merged_roads_0_2_5kmh from the drop-down list.

  • For Start Points, select study_area_educational_facilities from the drop-down list.

  • Keep the check-box in front of Selected features only checked.
  • Ensure you only select 1 feature point

  • For Unique Point ID field, select Name from the drop-down list.

  • For Size of Iso-Area (distance or time value), type 1800.

  • For Contour Interval, type 300.

  • For Path type to calculate, select Fastest Path (time optimization) from the drop-down list.

  • For Direction field, select oneway from the drop-down list.

  • For Value for forward direction, type F.

  • For Value for backward direction, type T.

  • For Value for both directions, type B.

  • For Speed field, select speed from the drop-down list.

Keep the rest of the entries as default.

Your screen should look similar to the screenshot below.

When you are ready to run the operation,

  • click on Run button.

The process will take some time to complete. Usually not going to take more than 5 minutes for a standard 64bit machine.

When the operation completed, two new temporary layers will be added onto Layer panel and display on QGIS View window. One of the output is called Output Polygon which shows the 30-minutes walking-time service area of an Education Facility as shown in figure below.

  • Save the output polygon as college_fid_4 in a folder titled Walking(30mins) that is located in the folder titled Education Facilities that is located in the overarching folder titled Fastest Distance Analysis as shown in the screenshot below

Repeat the above steps using the Fastest Distance Method separately for the Education Facilities, Healthcare Facilities and Religious Places.

Your output should look like the screenshots below:

  1. College_fid_5

  1. School_fid_6

  1. university_fid_6421

  1. Fid_217_community_center

  1. Fid_294_shopping_mall

  1. FID_18_mosque

  1. FID_17_MOSQUE

  1. FID_16_MOSQUE

  1. FID_15_MOSQUE

  1. FID_14_MOSQUE

  1. FID_12_MOSQUE

  1. FID_11_MOSQUE

  1. FID_7_MOSQUE

  1. FID_6_MOSQUE

  1. FID_3_MOSQUE

  1. FID_5_MOSQUE

  1. FID_2_MOSQUE

  1. FID_1_MOSQUE

  1. FID_13_MOSQUE

Lastly, the screenshot below shows the overall fastest distance analysis for all potential evacuation centres:

2. Combining the Evacuation Centres:

Next, we are going to combine all the points for the evacuation centres and then symbolise the points with a specific icon.

  • At Processing, Click on Toolbox

  • Search “Merge”
  • Click on “Merge vector layers”

  • Click on “Input Layers”

  • Tick the following layers shown in the screenshot below:

  • Click OK
  • Choose the correct Project CRS
  • Click RUN

Your temporary Merge layer would appear and it should look similar to the screenshot below:

DIY:  Save the temporary layer into GeoPackage format. Name the output layer as Potential Evacuation Centres.

Now, we are going to symbolise the Potential Evacuation Centres.

  • At Layers panel, click on Potential Evacuation Centres layer to make it active.
  • Right-click on Potential Evacuation Centres and select Properties from the context menu.

The Layer Properties dialog window appears.

  • Click on the Symbology tab.

Your screen should look similar to the screenshot below.

The Symbol selector dialog window appears.

  • From Marker, click on Simple marker.
  • For Symbol layer type, select SVG maker from the drop-down list.
  • Scroll down the dialog window until you can see the SVG Browser and search for “House” and double-click on the one in the middle, like the screenshot below.

DIY: Change the size value and fill colour and observe the differences.

  • When you are done, click on the OK button.

You will return to Layer Properties dialog window.

  • At the Layer Properties dialog window, click on Apply button to update the changes.
  • To close the Layer Properties dialog window, click on OK button.

Your screen should look similar to the figure below.

3. Merging different zones of Evacuation Centres:

From the analysis output of the previous section, we realised that some evacuation centres have overlap with other evacuation centres. Therefore, we are now going to merge the areas and proceed to perform another round of fastest distance analysis on the merged areas.

  • In the layer panel, click on “Merged Evacuation Centres” to activate it
  • Right click on attributes table to select the points as shown below:

  • DIY: Using what you have learnt previously, perform the same fastest distance analysis on the selected points

Your output should look like the screenshot below:

  • Export and save the output layer as Merged_1

DIY: Repeat the steps above for the next few merged points.

  1. Merged_2:
  1. Merged_3:
  1. Merged_4:
  1. Merged_5:
  1. Merged_6:
  1. Merged_7:
  1. Merged_8:

After attaining the 8 different Merged zones, we are now going to merge all 8 layers into 1.

DIY: Using the steps learnt previously, merge the 8 layers into 1 and save the output as Service_Area (Minutes)

DIY: Edit the legend to show the timing in minutes with a 5 minute interval, up to 30 minutes.

Your results should look like the screenshot below:

Since the layers still overlap each other by a bit, remove the timings from 20 minutes onwards. Now your results should look like the screenshot below:

4. Creating Map for Evacuation Centre with QGIS Print Layout:

In this section, you will learn how to use QGIS Print Layout platform to create a land use map for printing or publishing purposes.

  • Firstly, reshape QGIS Window until the white spaces in the GIS layer as minimum as possible.

  • From the menu bar, select Project -> New Print Layout.

Create Print Layout dialog window appears.

  • Provide the layout with an appropriate title such as Potential Evacuation Centre Map.
  • Click on OK button when it is ready

A new Print Layout dialog window appears.

  • From the menu bar, click on on Zoom full button  to display the full extent of Print Layout window.

Next, we will add the Land Use map layer onto the layout.

  • From the menu bar, select Add Item -> Add Map.
  • Once the Add Map mode is active, hold the left mouse button and drag a rectangle where you want to insert the map like shown below
  • Release your left finger from the left mouse button.

Your screen should look similar to the screenshot below.

Let us adjust the map scale.

  • From the Item Properties panel, look for Main Properties then enter 38700 as Scale value. (Note: Use other rounding values deem appropriate for your layout)

In order to prevent the view on the layout changes when we turn on/off some layers or change their styles, it is important for us to lock the layers and styles.

  • Scroll the Main Properties panel down until Layers appears.
  • Click on the check box in front of Lock layers and Lock styles for layers.

Next, we will add grid reference for the map.

  • From the Items Properties panel, scroll down until Grids sub-panel appears.

  • Click on +

A new grid frame called Grid 1 is added as shown below.

Next ,we are going to add a 1000m by 1000m grid on the layout.

  • Click on Modify Grid button.
  • Scroll down until Appearance sub-panel appears.
  • For X, enter 1000.
  • For Y, enter 1000.
  • Click on the drop-down list behind Line style.
  • Choose one of the light gray colour from the color panel.

Notice that a light gray grid frame is added on the layout.

Next, we are going to turn on the coordinates.

  • Scroll down the Map Grid Properties panel until Draw Coordinates sub-panel appears.
  • Click on the check-box in front of Draw Coordinates.

By default the grid reference appears on the four axis of the map layout. We are going to turn off the grid reference on the right and bottom of the layout.

  • From the Right sub-panel, click on the drop-down list and select Disable.
  • DIY: Repeat the step you learned to turn off the bottom grid reference.

The map layout should look similar to the screenshot below.

Now, we are going to add map legend onto the layout.

  • From the menu bar, select Add Item -> Add Legend.
  • Scroll down Item Properties and go to legend
  • From Legend Items sub-panel, click on the check-box in front of Only show items inside linked map.
  • Remove OpenStreetMap from the legend

Now we are going to add scale bar onto the layout.

  • From the menu bar, select Add Item -> Add Scale Bar.
  • Press on the left mouse button, drag a window at the lower left corner of the layout as shown below.
  • Release the left mouse button.
  • From Unit sub-panel, click on the drop-down list behind Scalebar units and select Kilometers from the drop-down list.
  • From Segment sub-panel, at right, type 4.
  • Change “Fixed Width” to 0.5 units

Notice that a scale bar has been added onto the lower left corner of the layout.

Next, we will add a north arrow on top of the scale bar.

  • From the menu bar, select Add Item -> Add North Arrow.
  • Press on the left mouse button and drag a small window onto of the scale bar.
  • Release the left mouse button.

Notice that a north arrow has been added onto the layout.

Next, we are going to add layout title.

  • From the menu bar, select Add Item -> Add Label.
  • Press on the left mouse button and drag a small but long window at the top of the map box.
  • At the Main Properties, type the following text “Map of Potential Evacuation Centres in Derna”
  • From the appearance sub-panel, click on the drop-down list behind Font.
  • Change the font size to 24.
  • For Horizontal alignment, click on the radio button in front of Center.
  • For Vertical alignment, click on the radio button in front of Middle.

The print layout should look similar to the screenshot below.

  • Lastly, remember to click on the Save  button to save the layout.

In QGIS, the composed map layout can be exported into three formats, namely: Image, SVG and PDF.

  • To export, click on File from the menu bar and select on of the format list below.

Accessibility Mapping

1. Add roads layer

1.1 Create merged roads layer for scenario 1_2_5kmh

In this map, it aims to analyse the accessibility for population in high risk zone to evacuate. With guidance from prof Kam, this maps considers the assumption that population groups are reluctant to evacuation their settlements until the last minute, where flood conditions prove to be worsening. Hence, it considers the scenario of flooded surroundings that still allows population to move albeit at the very slow speed, given impedance by flooded surroundings.

Using the roads layer created previously, select roads classified under the high risk zone and change the speed limit from 0km/h to 1km/h.

2. Add high risk population layer

First, import data source for buildings footprint in Libya from OSM into qGIS.

It is observed that a hexagon grid of 100m by 100m can act as a suitable proxy for a ‘population region’. Hence, we create a hexagon grid of 100 by 100 using Research tools -> Create Grid with the following settings below.

2.1 Identify high risk population regions by hexagon

Select the population hexagon regions based on the high risk flood zones

For a more accurate analysis, we will count number of buildings based on hexagon layer:

  1. Get centroid of buildings using realcentroid plugin

  1. Count number of buildings within hexagon:
  2. Select the population regions (hexagons) that has at least one building count

  1. Sele Create centroids using Centroids tool to represent these population regions.

3. Add potential evacuation sites layer

  • Import the 20 evacuation sites identified previously as vector layer

4. Compute Accessibility Map by fastest time

Under processing tools, find QNEAT OD Matrix from Layers as Table tool to run OD Matrix analysis with the respective settings:

  • Set network layer as merged_roads_1_2_5kmh
  • Set From-point layer (demand) as centroids layer
  • Set To-point layer (supply) as final evaluation sites layer
  • Set optimisation criterion as “Time Optimisation”

  • 4.1 Create OD Matrix

4.2 Process NULL values

Based on the output table, there are NULL values observed. Upon inspection is this likely due to lack of a road network connecting points between centroids to evacuation site.

This limitation is due to the network constraint of our method. However, can be prevented in future works using terrain based analysis.

To prevent wrong selections by the subsequent SQL selection statement, we will assume these NULL values as highly inaccessible by setting them to a high value.

First, select the rows with NULL values using the Select by Expression tool

Next identify the max value that has been computed using Statistics for Fields tool under Processing Tools.

We observe the max value to be 14441

Hence we replace NULL values to 15000 (>14441) so that they will not be considered in our next step.

4.3 Get fastest time from population points to nearest evacuation site

Using the following SQL select statement, we aim to find the shortest time required for population regions to reach nearest evacuation site.

Convert time from seconds to minutes and round them up for easier interpretation

4.4 Create Chloropleth map

  1. Based on the SQL Selection output, join this layer to the hexagon layer for high risk population, mapped based on origin id to FID of hexagon layer

  1. Thereafter using Symbology tools, categorise travel “cost” graduated by the following respective time boundaries:

5. Estimate demand for each evacuation site:

5.1 Count no. of nearest population region - origin_id, for each evacuation site

  1. Select layer to execute SQL statement

  1. Compute number of population region (origin id) that is nearest to the respective potential evacuation site. Save output layer as evac_site_demand_estimation

Get total number of buildings count by evacuation centre

  1. Join Vector Layer with the evacuation sites layer

  1. Update destination sites with NULL values as 0, suggesting no population region identifies it as the nearest evacuation site.

  1. Plot chloropleth map Graduated by the Demand counts

Bar plot of population demand for each evacuation site

We observe that the demand load for each evacuation site is rather unevenly distributed, where a few evacuation sites are mapped as nearest sites for a significantly high number of population regions.

 

Additionally, observe that evacuation site 5, 7, 17 does not seem to serve as a nearest evacuation site to any population region. This is as expected given their location being further away from the high risk zones. However, they can be considered for population regions that can reach them as second nearest sites so as to better distribute the demand load for the other sites.

5.2 Estimate population demand

Approximate average number of population per building based on the following formula:

Total population in Derna City / Total number of buildings in Derna City

Based on [1] total population in Derna City is around 90 000. Based on the buildings data layer, total number of buildings is around 13692. Although buildings can be differentiated to various types, future analysis can look deeper into a better estimate of population demand approximation.

Broadly, in this analysis we estimate population per building as

90000 [1] / 13692 = 6.5732 = 7 pax

Next we use SQL Statement to extract total counts of buildings from nearest population regions.

Estimate population by pax based on the 7 pax per building generalisation.

Finally, join vector layer to hexagon layer of population regions.

Build chloropleth map.

Custom settings:
